1.text: Wisdom hath built herself a house, she hath hewn her out seven pillars.

2.text: She hath slain her victims, mingled her wine, and set forth her table.

3.text: She hath sent her maids to invite to the tower, and to the walls of the city:

4.text: Whosoever is a little one, let him come to me. And to the unwise she said:

5.text: Come, eat my bread, and drink the wine which I have mingled for you.

6.text: Forsake childishness, and live, and walk by the ways of prudence.

7.text: He that teacheth a scorner, doth an injury to himself: and he that rebuketh a wicked man, getteth himself a blot.

8.text: Rebuke not a scorner lest he hate thee. Rebuke a wise man, and he will love thee.

9.text: Give an occasion to a wise man, and wisdom shall be added to him. Teach a just man, and he shall make haste to receive it.

10.text: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy is prudence.

11.text: For by me shall thy days be multiplied, and years of life shall be added to thee.

12.text: If thou be wise, thou shalt be so to thyself: and if a scorner, thou alone shalt bear the evil.

13.text: A foolish woman and clamorous, and full of allurements, and knowing nothing at all,

14.text: Sat at the door of her house, upon a seat, in a high place of the city,

15.text: To call them that pass by the way, and go on their journey:

16.text: He that is a little one, let him turn to me. And to the fool she said:

17.text: Stolen waters are sweeter, and hid den bread is more pleasant.

18.text: And he did not know that giants are there, and that her guests are in the depths of hell. The Parables of Solomon
